What's the silliest scientific research you ever heard of?
Ever year, the Annals of Improbable Research scour scholarly journals for the wackiest, silliest, craziest research studies published that year. And those intrepid scientists--who studied things such as: electronically modifying the sound of a potato chip to make the person chewing the chip believe it to be crisper and fresher than it really is; discovering that the fleas that live on a dog can jump higher than the fleas that live on a cat; discovering that slime molds can solve puzzles (yes, these are all real research studies)--receive an Ignobel prize, given out by real Nobel Prize winning scientists. The award ceremony is Thursday night, but costs $40.

So I'm going to the lectures instead--5-minute mini-lectures on each topic, with challenging questions from the audience encouraged (get your Nerd Brain ready!).
Let's meet at 12:30, so we can chat beforehand. I will hold seats until 12:45--after that, you're on your own. One person will be at the doors with Meetup sign, another will be inside holding seats with Meetup sign.


Remember--if you RSVP Yes and don't show up, it's rude to both the organizer and other attendees who were expecting you.

Links and directions are below; site is MIT's main campus--from Memorial Drive, in the big MIT yard/mall/grassy area, it's the building smack in the center of the U.



http://improbable.com... (scroll down--they have a lot of blank space at top of page)

map & directions: http://whereis.mit.ed...

The Ig Informal Lectures
Saturday, Oct 3, 2009, 1:00 pm.
MIT Building 10, Room 250
77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge
(Click here for a map and directions)
FREE ADMISSION -- but seating is limited
A half-afternoon of improbably funny, informative, brief (5 minutes each, plus a few questions & answers with the audience), high-spirited public lectures, in which the new Ig Nobel Prize winners (and a few past winners, too) attempt to explain what they did, and why they did it.
This free event is organized in cooperation with the MIT Press Bookstore.
